deliberation: I considered whether the verse is purely instructional for a sign-act or already contains figurative meaning. In light of the chapter, Ezekiel’s shaved and weighed hair is a symbolic representation of Jerusalem’s population and their fate, and the address 'son of man' is a conventional idiomatic designation for a mortal human. Thus I identify (1) an idiomatic title 'ben-adam' and (2) the symbolic weighing/dividing of hair as a metaphorical sign-act of judgment.

instances.english_text: And you, O mortal (son of man)
target: Ezekiel as a finite human being
posture: Divine address that underscores Ezekiel’s lowly human status before God
instances.explanation: The expression "ben‑adam" literally means "son of man" but functions idiomatically as a title for a mere human, emphasizing Ezekiel’s mortality and subordinate status before the divine speaker.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהַעֲבַרְתָּ עַל־רֹאשְׁךָ וְעַל־זְקָנֶךָ וְלָקַחְתָּ לְךָ מֹאזְנֵי מִשְׁקָל וְחִלַּקְתָּם
instances.english_text: pass it over your head and beard. Then take scales and divide the hair.
target: The people of Jerusalem and their divided destinies
vehicle: Ezekiel’s shaved hair weighed and divided in scales
hair portions in a weighing ritual
ground: Being cut off, measured out, and apportioned to different outcomes
posture: A prophetic symbolic action portraying coming judgment on the populace
instances.explanation: Ezekiel’s hair, shaved, weighed, and divided, functions as a symbolic representation of the population of Jerusalem being measured and apportioned to different fates; the action is a metaphorical sign‑act of God’s precise judgment.

deliberation: Here the hair from v.1 is treated in three different ways that symbolically correspond to three fates of the people (fire, sword, scattering), and the phrase 'scatter to the wind' is a common figurative idiom for dispersion to all directions. I treat the distribution of hair as one extended metaphorical sign‑act and 'scatter to the wind' as a distinct idiomatic metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: שְׁלִשִׁית בָּאוּר תַּבְעִיר ... וְלָקַחְתָּ אֶת־הַשְּׁלִשִׁית תַּכֶּה בַחֶרֶב ... וְהַשְּׁלִשִׁית תִּזְרֶה לָרוּחַ
instances.english_text: destroy a third part in fire in the city, take a third and strike it with the sword all around the city, and scatter a third to the wind
target: Three segments of Jerusalem’s population and their respective fates
subgroups of a community under judgment
vehicle: Three thirds of Ezekiel’s hair burned, struck, and scattered
portions of hair under different treatments
ground: Correspondence between the divided hair’s fates and the people’s burning, slaughter, and exile
symbolic mapping of fate through treatment of hair
posture: A divinely commanded sign‑act visually depicting how God will judge the people
instances.explanation: The three treatments of the hair—burning, striking with a sword, and scattering—metaphorically portray the three ways segments of Jerusalem will be destroyed or dispersed. The hair continues to function as a symbolic stand‑in for the people.

instances.english_text: and scatter a third to the wind
vehicle: Chaff or dust blown by the wind in every direction
ground: Loss of rootedness and uncontrolled dispersion over a wide area
posture: YHWH depicting the exile as a total, wind‑like scattering
instances.explanation: The idiom 'scatter to the wind' uses the image of particles blown by wind to metaphorically describe people being thoroughly dispersed into exile in all directions.

deliberation: This continues the hair sign‑act, but now only a few hairs are taken and bound in Ezekiel’s garment, which symbolically portray a preserved remnant. I treat this as a single metaphorical instance within the ongoing symbolic action.

instances.hebrew_text: וְלָקַחְתָּ מִשָּׁם מְעַט בְּמִסְפָּר וְצַרְתָּ אוֹתָם בִּכְנָפֶיךָ
instances.english_text: Take also a few from there and tie them up in your skirts.
target: The small remnant of Israel that will survive
vehicle: A few hairs bound securely in the edge of a garment
small protected bundle of hair in a fold of cloth
ground: Being small in number yet guarded and kept close for safekeeping
preservation and protection of a remnant
posture: A sign‑act expressing God’s intention to preserve a minority even amid judgment
instances.explanation: The 'few hairs' tied into Ezekiel’s skirts metaphorically represent a small remnant of the people preserved and kept safe by God, using the image of something guarded in a garment fold.

deliberation: The verse intensifies the sign‑act: some of the preserved hairs are burned, and a 'fire' is said to go out upon all Israel. Here hair continues to symbolize people, 'fire' functions as a metaphor for destructive judgment (likely war/disaster), and 'house of Israel' is a standard metonymy for the people themselves.

instances.hebrew_text: וּמֵהֶם עוֹד תִּקָּח וְהִשְׁלַכְתָּ אוֹתָם אֶל־תּוֹךְ הָאֵשׁ וְשָׂרַפְתָּ אֹתָם בָּאֵשׁ
instances.english_text: And take some more of them and cast them into the fire, and burn them in the fire.
target: A further portion of the people, even from among the remnant
vehicle: Previously preserved hairs now thrown into and consumed by fire
ground: Exposure to renewed and intensified destruction despite prior preservation
posture: A prophetic sign‑act showing that even among the remnant some will yet face severe judgment
instances.explanation: The burning of some of the remnant hairs continues the metaphorical use of hair for people, illustrating that even among those apparently saved, some will still be subjected to destructive judgment.

instances.english_text: From this a fire shall go out upon the whole House of Israel.
vehicle: A fire going out and spreading
ground: Rapid, consuming, and far‑reaching destructive effect
posture: God portrays his judgment as a consuming fire emanating from within the people’s midst
image of purging yet devastating wrath
instances.explanation: The 'fire' that goes out upon the whole House of Israel is not literal flame from burnt hair but a metaphor for comprehensive destructive judgment that will engulf the nation.

instances.english_text: the whole House of Israel
target: The people of Israel as a nation
ground: A house as a single entity made up of many members
posture: Covenantal language emphasizing Israel as God’s household
instances.explanation: The phrase 'house of Israel' uses 'house' metonymically for the people who belong to it, a conventional way of referring to the nation as a single unified household.

deliberation: The verse identifies 'this Jerusalem' as something God has set in the midst of the nations. Jerusalem is referred to with a feminine pronoun, and the city functions as a stand‑in for its human community. Thus we have both personification of the city and metonymic use of its name for its inhabitants.

instances.english_text: This is Jerusalem; I set her in the midst of nations
target: The human community identified with Jerusalem
vehicle: Jerusalem as a feminized city placed in a central location
city as a woman placed among others
ground: The city embodies and represents its people and occupies a central, conspicuous role among surrounding nations
posture: God addresses Jerusalem as a person-like entity to highlight her privileged, visible position
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is described with a feminine pronoun and treated as if she were a person placed among other nations; at the same time, the city name stands metonymically for its people and their covenantal role.

deliberation: The verse speaks of Jerusalem as 'she' who rebelled and acted wickedly, and then shifts to 'they' who rejected and did not walk in God’s laws. This continues the personification of the city as an acting agent and uses the city as a metonym for its inhabitants. The legal language itself is straightforward, not figurative.

instances.hebrew_text: וַתֶּמֶר אֶת־מִשְׁפָּטַי ... אֲשֶׁר סְבִיבוֹתֶיהָ ... כִּי בְמִשְׁפָּטַי מָאָסוּ
instances.english_text: But she rebelled against My rules ... the countries round about her; for they rejected My rules
target: The people of Jerusalem/Israel under indictment
vehicle: Jerusalem depicted as a woman who rebels, surrounded by other lands
ground: The city stands for its inhabitants, and their collective disobedience is cast as a personal act of rebellion by 'her'
posture: God frames the community’s sin as the betrayal of a personified Jerusalem, heightening the sense of personal offense
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is personified as a woman who rebels against God’s judgments, while the city name and pronouns function metonymically for the actual people who have rejected God’s laws.

deliberation: The main imagery here is covenantal/legal and comparative. The notable figurative expression is 'walking in my statutes' as an idiom for living in obedience, based on the common metaphor of life as a path one walks. I treat this as a single metaphorical idiom.

instances.english_text: you have not walked in My laws
target: Israel’s pattern of obedience or disobedience
vehicle: Walking along a path or way
ground: Just as walking a path entails sustained movement in a direction, obedience entails consistent conduct according to a standard
ordered progress according to a way
posture: Covenant obedience is portrayed as following a prescribed path, so failure is refusal to take that path
instances.explanation: The expression 'walk in my laws' is a metaphorical idiom: adherence to God’s statutes is pictured as walking along a prescribed path, so not 'walking' in them denotes disobedient living.

deliberation: I looked for metaphors of judgment or emotional language. The key expression is 'hinneni alayikh' ('I am against you'), which uses spatial language ('upon/against') idiomatically for opposition. The rest is largely straightforward judicial language.

instances.english_text: I, in turn, am against you
ground: Physical opposition or attack is conceptualized as being 'against' someone’s person
posture: God declares a stance of active opposition rather than protection, reversing expected covenant favor
instances.explanation: The phrase 'I am against you' uses spatial language metaphorically and idiomatically to express God’s hostile stance and active opposition toward Jerusalem.

deliberation: This verse emphasizes the unprecedented nature of the coming judgment. The claim that God will do what He has never done and will never do again is expressed in absolute terms that likely function rhetorically as hyperbole to stress the intensity and uniqueness of the disaster.

instances.hebrew_text: וְעָשִׂיתִי בָךְ אֵת אֲשֶׁר לֹא־עָשִׂיתִי וְאֵת אֲשֶׁר־לֹא־אֶעֱשֶׂה כָמֹהוּ עוֹד
instances.english_text: I will do among you what I have never done, and the like of which I will never do again.
target: The severity and distinctiveness of the coming judgment
vehicle: Absolute claims of never before and never again
ground: Hyperbolic 'never before/never again' speech heightens perception of something as incomparable
posture: God underscores the incomparable horror of this judgment to shock and warn the hearers
instances.explanation: The sweeping claim that such an act has never occurred and will never recur functions as hyperbolic rhetoric to stress the unparalleled severity of the impending catastrophe, rather than as a precise historical statistic.

deliberation: The shocking statement that parents and children will eat one another may be literal under extreme siege conditions but is also highly rhetorical and may function hyperbolically to depict utter horror. Additionally, 'scatter all your survivors to every spirit/wind' is a well-established idiom/metaphor for comprehensive dispersion in all directions.

instances.hebrew_text: אָבוֹת יֹאכְלוּ בָנִים בְּתוֹכֵךְ וּבָנִים יֹאכְלוּ אֲבוֹתָם
instances.english_text: parents shall eat their children in your midst, and children shall eat their parents.
target: The extremity of famine and social breakdown in Jerusalem
vehicle: Parents and children resorting to cannibalism of each other
ground: Cannibalism within the family represents the most extreme imaginable breakdown of natural bonds and desperation
utter reversal of normal care and affection
posture: The prophecy uses a horrifying scenario to convey how desperate and unnatural conditions will become under judgment
shock rhetoric to underline curse severity
instances.explanation: The depiction of parents and children eating one another, whether or not it ever became fully literal, functions as an extreme image that expresses the depth of famine and moral collapse accompanying God’s judgment.

instances.english_text: and I will scatter all your survivors in every direction (to every wind).
target: The dispersion of surviving inhabitants into exile
vehicle: Particles or chaff scattered by winds from every direction
ground: The wind’s capacity to drive light objects indiscriminately in all directions parallels the uprooting and scattering of people far from home
complete dispersal and lack of control
posture: God portrays the exile as an uncontrollable wind‑driven scattering of survivors
graphic depiction of the end of settled life
instances.explanation: The idiom 'scatter ... to every wind' uses the image of the wind’s dispersing power to metaphorically describe the comprehensive, directionless scattering of Jerusalem’s surviving population.

deliberation: The verse uses cultic terminology of defilement straightforwardly. The notable figurative expression is 'my eye will not spare,' where the 'eye' is metonymy for compassion and 'sparing' is idiomatic for showing pity.

instances.english_text: and My eye will not pity (spare)
target: God’s exercise (or withholding) of compassion in judgment
vehicle: An eye that either looks with compassion or refuses to spare
ground: The direction and quality of one’s gaze often signals compassion or lack thereof, so the eye stands for the inner disposition of mercy
visual attention as indicator of pity
posture: God declares that His usual compassionate regard will be withdrawn in this act of judgment
instances.explanation: The phrase 'my eye will not spare' uses the eye metonymically for God’s compassionate regard and functions as an idiom meaning that He will show no pity in the coming judgment.

deliberation: The verse explains explicitly the threefold division hinted at in the hair sign‑act (pestilence/famine, sword, scattering). The distribution itself is literal in content, but 'scatter to every wind' recurs as an idiomatic metaphor, and 'I will unsheathe the sword after them' uses 'sword' metonymically for ongoing warfare pursuing the exiles.

instances.english_text: and I will scatter one-third in every direction (to every wind)
target: That third of the population destined for exile
vehicle: Objects or chaff scattered by the winds
ground: Complete lack of rootedness and direction as something is blown wherever the wind takes it
thorough dispersion and loss of control
posture: God pictures His judgment as a wind‑like scattering of a third of the people
emphasis on the extent of dispersion
instances.explanation: Again the idiom of scattering to the wind uses the imagery of wind‑driven scattering to represent comprehensive exile of a portion of the people.

instances.english_text: and I will unsheathe the sword after them.
vehicle: A drawn sword pursuing after fleeing people
ground: A sword symbolizes warfare and lethal force that can chase down and destroy
posture: God depicts His judgment as a personified sword of war that continues to follow the exiled third
instances.explanation: Here 'sword' stands metonymically for warfare and deadly attack; the image of unsheathing it after them portrays God’s judgment as an ongoing, pursuing violence even beyond the city’s fall.

deliberation: This verse is rich in theological emotion language: God speaks of venting His anger, satisfying His fury, and being 'comforted.' These are anthropopathic metaphors, describing God’s actions and resultant state in human emotional terms; in particular, anger and fury are treated almost as entities that can be 'quieted' or 'satisfied.'

instances.hebrew_text: וְכָלָה אַפִּי וַהֲנִחוֹתִי חֲמָתִי בָּם וְהִנֶּחָמְתִּי
instances.english_text: I will vent all My anger and satisfy My fury upon them; and I will be comforted.
target: God’s exercise of judgment and the cessation of His wrath
vehicle: Human anger and fury that can be poured out until a person is comforted or calmed
person-like emotions that can be satisfied
ground: As with human anger, divine judgment is portrayed as an emotional burden that, when fully expressed, leads to a state of 'being comforted' or at rest
transition from agitated wrath to resolved calm
posture: The text adopts human emotional language (anthropopathism) to describe God’s zealous commitment to justice and the eventual completion of His punitive work
instances.explanation: God’s 'anger' and 'fury' are described in human emotional terms as something that can be fully vented and thereby lead to His being 'comforted'; this is an anthropopathic metaphor in which divine judgment is expressed through the imagery of human emotional processes.

deliberation: The verse says God will make 'you' (Jerusalem) a ruin and reproach among the nations, to the eyes of every passerby. The key figurative aspect is again the personified, feminized 'you' referring to Jerusalem as a representative of its people (metonymy plus personification). The terms 'ruin' and 'reproach' themselves here are straightforward descriptors, not obviously metaphorical.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאֶתְּנֵךְ לְחָרְבָּה וּלְחֶרְפָּה בַּגּוֹיִם אֲשֶׁר סְבִיבוֹתָיִךְ
instances.english_text: I will make you a ruin and a mockery among the nations round about you
target: Jerusalem’s community and its reputation among other peoples
vehicle: A feminized 'you' (the city) made into an object of desolation and taunting
ground: The city embodies the people, and her becoming a ruin and reproach encapsulates both physical destruction and social shame
corporate humiliation as if of a person
posture: God speaks to Jerusalem as a person whose downfall will be observed and mocked by all around
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is addressed as 'you' and treated as a person whose fate and disgrace will be seen by 'every passerby'; the city functions both as a personified figure and as a metonymy for its inhabitants and their humiliation.

deliberation: Here Jerusalem is said to 'be' reproach, insult, discipline, and horror to the nations. The city is personified and equated with abstract qualities that it will embody for others—a living warning. This is best treated as a metaphor in which Jerusalem becomes a paradigm or object lesson, as well as continuation of the personification of the city.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיִיתָ חֶרְפָּה וּגְדוּפָה מוּסָר וּמְשַׁמָּה לַגּוֹיִם אֲשֶׁר סְבִיבוֹתָיִךְ
instances.english_text: you shall be a mockery and a derision, a warning and a horror, to the nations round about you
target: Jerusalem as an example to other nations
Israel’s judged condition as a didactic sign
vehicle: A person or object that itself is reproach, insult, instruction, and devastation to observers
ground: The city’s judged state will serve as a visible, terrifying lesson and object of scorn for others
posture: God casts Jerusalem as a living parable of judgment whose fate will instruct and warn surrounding nations
instances.explanation: By saying Jerusalem will 'be' reproach, insult, discipline, and horror, the text metaphorically portrays the city (personified and metonymic for its people) as a living warning sign and object lesson for the surrounding nations.

deliberation: This verse contains two well-known metaphors: 'the evil arrows of famine' likens famine to deadly arrows God sends, and 'break the staff of bread' portrays bread/food as a staff that supports life. Both are distinct metaphorical expressions, not merely variations of one another.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּשַׁלְּחִי אֶת־חִצֵּי הָרָעָב הָרָעִים בָּהֶם אֲשֶׁר הָיוּ לְמַשְׁחִית
instances.english_text: When I loose the deadly arrows of famine against them, which were for destruction
target: The destructive impact of famine sent by God
vehicle: Arrows shot at people to kill and destroy
ground: Like arrows, famine comes from a distance at God’s initiative, strikes its victims, and brings death
posture: God is depicted as a warrior loosing famine like arrows against the people
instances.explanation: Famine is metaphorically described as 'arrows' that God sends, using martial imagery to portray famine as a targeted, lethal instrument of divine judgment.

instances.english_text: and break your staff of bread.
target: The removal of basic sustenance and stability of life
vehicle: A staff that supports a person’s weight, now broken
ground: As a staff supports a person physically, bread supports life; breaking the staff symbolizes removing that support
posture: God describes His action as taking away the very support of life, not just reducing luxury
instances.explanation: The 'staff of bread' metaphor presents food as a supporting staff; to 'break' it is to remove the support of life itself, an idiomatic way of describing the cutting off of basic sustenance.

deliberation: The verse lists covenant curse elements: famine, wild beasts, pestilence, blood, and the sword. Most are straightforward; however, 'the sword' is a conventional metonymy for warfare/violent invasion, and its 'bringing' upon the people uses that figure.

instances.english_text: and I will bring the sword upon you.
target: Invading warfare and violent military destruction
vehicle: A sword as an instrument of killing
ground: The sword is emblematic of warfare and bloodshed; bringing the sword means bringing war
instrument stands for the whole conflict
posture: God states that He Himself will be the one to initiate war against His people by sending invading forces
attribution of invasion to divine judgment
instances.explanation: Here 'the sword' is a metonymy for warfare and violent invasion; saying 'I will bring the sword upon you' figuratively means that God will cause war to come upon Jerusalem.
